gov.va.isaac.drools.manager

Class DroolsCommitListener

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.va.isaac.drools.manager.DroolsCommitListener
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    CommitListenerI, ServicesToPreloadI, VetoableChangeListener, EventListener

    @Service
 @Singleton
 @Named(value="Drools PreCommit")
public class DroolsCommitListener
extends Object
implements CommitListenerI, VetoableChangeListener, ServicesToPreloadI
    DroolsCommitListener
    Author:
    Dan Armbrust

    • Method Detail

      • loadRequested

        public void loadRequested()
        Description copied from interface: ServicesToPreloadI
        Implementers don't actually have to do anything when called here... they can do the init in the constructor if the prefer. This is just to prevent the compiler from doing something silly and dropping the for-loop over the ServiceToPreloadI objects, when it looks like nothing is actually being done. Implementors may do something here, however, if they prefer to have the constructor do nothing, and instead, handle the loading when loadRequested is called. This will be called during the startup sequence, after the database init has completed. If any expensive works needs to be done as a result of loadRequested - it should be done in a background thread - loadRequested should return immediately.
        Specified by:
        loadRequested in interface ServicesToPreloadI
        See Also:
        ServicesToPreloadI.loadRequested()

        public void shutdown()
        Description copied from interface: ServicesToPreloadI

      • getListenerName

        public String getListenerName()
        Description copied from interface: CommitListenerI
        Returns the HK2 service name of this listener. This should return the same string as the @Named (value="the name") annotation on the implementation of the class.
        Specified by:
        getListenerName in interface CommitListenerI
        See Also:
        CommitListenerI.getListenerName()

      • enable

        public void enable()
        Description copied from interface: CommitListenerI
        Tell the listener that it MAY enable itself (it does not have to). A listener may be primarily controlled by a user preference, for example. While CommitListenerI.disable() overrides the user preferences, and orders the listener disabled - this call only informs the user that it is no longer being overridden - and may return to the enabled state if that was the users preference.
        Specified by:
        enable in interface CommitListenerI
        See Also:
        CommitListenerI.enable()

      • disable

        public void disable()
        Description copied from interface: CommitListenerI
        Tell the listener to disable itself - either by unregistering upstream, or ignoring all commit related events until CommitListenerI.enable() is called.
        Specified by:
        disable in interface CommitListenerI
        See Also:
        CommitListenerI.disable()
